definition: A severe, life-threatening spectrum of mucocutaneous reactions characterized by extensive necrosis and detachment of the epidermis.
clinical: Presents with erythematous macules evolving rapidly to blisters and widespread skin sloughing. Mucosal involvement (mouth, eyes, genitals) is common. Often drug-induced (e.g., sulfonamides, anticonvulsants, live attenuated vaccines like FluMist) or associated with infections/immunizations. Risk increased in immunocompromised patients (AIDS).
pathogenesis: Cytotoxic lymphocyte-mediated immune reaction inducing extensive keratinocyte apoptosis.
macroscopic: Widespread blistering, skin sloughing (positive Nikolsky sign), extensive erosions appearing like burns.
microscopic: Subepidermal vesiculation with full-thickness epidermal necrosis. The cornified layer often remains 'pristine' (basket-weave orthokeratosis), indicating an acute process occurring faster than the time required for parakeratosis to form (under 2 weeks). Pauci-inflammatory infiltrate (sparse lymphocytes). Basal vacuolar alteration and dyskeratotic keratinocytes are seen in early lesions.
ancillary_studies: Direct Immunofluorescence (DIF) is typically negative (helps distinguish from autoimmune blistering diseases).
differential_diagnosis: Erythema Multiforme (major), Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome, Acute Graft-versus-Host Disease.
staging: SJS (<10% BSA), SJS/TEN overlap (10-30% BSA), TEN (>30% BSA).
prognosis_and_prediction: Life-threatening; high mortality rate correlated with body surface area involvement.

definition: A mechanobullous disorder caused by prolonged pressure leading to ischemia and necrosis of the skin and underlying structures.
clinical: Tense blisters arising at sites of pressure, often seen in immobilized patients or post-surgery. Can appear linear or follow pressure points. Lesions may be dusky or erythematous.
pathogenesis: Ischemic necrosis secondary to prolonged mechanical pressure.
macroscopic: Bullae at pressure sites, often with a surrounding rim of erythema.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister with little to no inflammation (pauci-inflammatory). Blood vessels appear congested/dilated. A key diagnostic feature is necrosis of the eccrine sweat glands (sweat coils), which are highly sensitive to pressure.
prognosis_and_prediction: Heals upon relief of pressure; risk of secondary infection.

related_figures.legend: Clinical appearance of linear blisters appearing post-surgically due to pressure. (Time: 773s)
Histology showing subepidermal split, congested vessels, and necrosis of deep eccrine glands. (Time: 951s)

definition: A mechanical blistering disorder caused by negative pressure separating the epidermis from the dermis.
clinical: Tense bullae, often circular or linear depending on the device used (e.g., cupping therapy).
pathogenesis: Mechanical separation of the epidermis from the dermis due to suction/negative pressure.
macroscopic: Circular or geometric blistering corresponding to the suction device.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister with minimal inflammation (pauci-inflammatory). Unlike pressure blisters, there is NO necrosis of the eccrine glands.
differential_diagnosis: Pressure bulla, Epidermolysis Bullosa, Bullous Pemphigoid.

related_figures.legend: Clinical appearance of circular blisters following cupping therapy. (Time: 1036s)
Histology showing clean subepidermal separation without eccrine necrosis. (Time: 1090s)

definition: The most common form of porphyria, characterized by photosensitivity and blistering on sun-exposed skin due to a defect in heme biosynthesis.
clinical: Vesicles, bullae, erosions, crusts, and scars primarily on dorsal hands (photo-distributed). Associated with hypertrichosis, liver disease, and alcohol use.
pathogenesis: Deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase leading to accumulation of porphyrins.
macroscopic: Tense blisters, erosions, milia, and scarring on sun-exposed sites.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister with minimal inflammation (pauci-inflammatory). 'Festooning' of the dermal papillae (rigid dermal papillae protruding into the blister cavity). 'Caterpillar bodies' (linear eosinophilic basement membrane material) may be seen in the blister roof.
ancillary_studies: DIF: Deposition of C3 and Immunoglobulins (IgG) around dermal blood vessels and at the DEJ. Urine studies: Elevated porphyrins (coral red fluorescence with Wood's lamp).
prognosis_and_prediction: Manageable with phlebotomy and avoidance of triggers.

definition: A group of inherited mechanobullous disorders characterized by skin fragility and blistering in response to minor trauma.
clinical: Blistering and erosions starting in infancy/childhood, induced by friction/trauma.
pathogenesis: Mutations in structural proteins of the cutaneous basement membrane zone (e.g., Keratins 5/14 in Simplex, Laminin-332 in Junctional, Collagen VII in Dystrophic).
macroscopic: Widespread blistering, scarring (in dystrophic forms), milia.
microscopic: Subepidermal (or intraepidermal for Simplex) vesiculation with little inflammation (pauci-inflammatory). Level of split correlates with the specific protein defect.
ancillary_studies: Immunofluorescence mapping or genetic testing to identify specific protein defect.
prognosis_and_prediction: Varies from mild to lethal depending on subtype.

related_figures.legend: Diagram illustrating target proteins at the DEJ (Keratins, Laminins, Collagen VII) affected in EB subtypes. (Time: 1395s)

definition: The most common autoimmune subepidermal blistering disease, typically affecting the elderly.
clinical: Tense blisters, often on an urticarial base. Intense pruritus. Can present with urticarial plaques (pre-bullous), annular lesions, or eczema-like rash. Bimodal age distribution (elderly and children).
pathogenesis: Autoantibodies against hemidesmosomal proteins BP180 (Collagen XVII) and BP230.
macroscopic: Tense bullae that do not rupture easily. Urticarial plaques.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister containing Eosinophils. Urticarial phase shows eosinophils lining the DEJ and 'eosinophilic spongiosis'. Neutrophils can be present but eosinophils are the hallmark.
ancillary_studies: DIF: Linear deposition of C3 and IgG along the basement membrane zone (BMZ). N-serrated pattern (vs U-serrated in EBA) may be seen but is difficult to distinguish.
differential_diagnosis: Epidermolysis Bullosa Acquisita (EBA), Bullous Arthropod Bite, Drug Eruptions.
prognosis_and_prediction: Generally chronic but treatable; significant morbidity in elderly.

definition: An exaggerated hypersensitivity reaction to an insect bite resulting in blister formation.
clinical: Grouped or linear blisters ('breakfast, lunch, dinner' sign).
macroscopic: Tense bullae on an erythematous base.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister with eosinophils. Distinguished from BP by tremendous dermal edema and a deep, wedge-shaped inflammatory infiltrate extending into the reticular dermis.
ancillary_studies: DIF is negative (helps distinguish from BP).

related_figures.legend: Clinical appearance of grouped bullous lesions. (Time: 2032s)

definition: A cutaneous manifestation of gluten-sensitive enteropathy (Celiac disease), characterized by intensely pruritic grouped vesicles.
clinical: Intensely pruritic papulovesicles on extensor surfaces (elbows, knees), buttocks, and scalp. Intact vesicles are rare due to scratching (excoriations common).
pathogenesis: IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase (anti-tTG) cross-react with epidermal transglutaminase, leading to neutrophil chemotaxis.
macroscopic: Grouped excoriations and crusts on extensor surfaces.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister with Neutrophils. Hallmark feature: Papillary dermal microabscesses (accumulations of neutrophils at the tips of dermal papillae).
ancillary_studies: DIF: Granular IgA deposition in the dermal papillae. Serology: Positive Anti-tissue transglutaminase (tTG).
differential_diagnosis: Linear IgA Bullous Dermatosis, Bullous Lupus, Scabies.
prognosis_and_prediction: Responds to gluten-free diet and Dapsone.

related_figures.legend: Clinical presentation on elbows with crusted lesions. (Time: 2103s)

definition: An autoimmune subepidermal blistering disease characterized by linear IgA deposition at the basement membrane zone.
clinical: Vesicles and bullae, sometimes arranged in a 'crown of jewels' (new vesicles surrounding an old crust). Can be idiopathic (Chronic Bullous Disease of Childhood) or drug-induced (commonly Vancomycin).
pathogenesis: Autoantibodies (IgA) targeting the 97 kDa portion of the BP180 antigen (BPAG2).
macroscopic: Annular or grouped blisters, 'string of pearls' or 'crown of jewels' appearance.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister with Neutrophils. Unlike DH, neutrophils tend to form a linear band along the DEJ rather than papillary microabscesses.
ancillary_studies: DIF: Linear IgA along the basement membrane zone.
prognosis_and_prediction: Good prognosis, especially for drug-induced cases upon withdrawal of the offender.

related_figures.legend: Widespread blistering in a child (Chronic Bullous Disease of Childhood). (Time: 2268s)
Clinical 'crown of jewels' sign with vesicles arranged in a ring. (Time: 2296s)

definition: A group of autoimmune blistering disorders predominantly affecting mucous membranes and leading to scarring.
clinical: Involvement of oral mucosa (desquamative gingivitis), ocular conjunctiva (symblepharon, scarring), and scalp. Significant morbidity due to scarring.
pathogenesis: Autoantibodies against various BMZ proteins, including BP180 and Laminin 5 (Laminin-332, associated with malignancy).
macroscopic: Erosions and scarring on mucosal surfaces.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister with Neutrophils (often more than BP) and eventual fibrosis/scarring. Eosinophils may be present.
ancillary_studies: DIF: Linear IgG and C3 at the BMZ (indistinguishable from BP).
prognosis_and_prediction: Chronic course with risk of blindness and airway stenosis; difficult to treat.

related_figures.legend: Text slide describing clinical features and autoantigens (Laminin 5, BPAG2). (Time: 2395s)

definition: An acute, self-limiting, often recurrent mucocutaneous hypersensitivity reaction characterized by target lesions.
clinical: Targetoid lesions (dusky center, pale ring, erythematous rim) on palms, soles, and extremities.
pathogenesis: Cell-mediated immune reaction, commonly triggered by infections (HSV, Mycoplasma).
macroscopic: Target lesions, sometimes with central blistering.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister mediated by Lymphocytes. Interface dermatitis with necrotic/dyskeratotic keratinocytes at the basal layer. The blister cavity often contains degenerated cellular debris ('messy').

related_figures.legend: Clinical appearance of target lesions. (Time: 2544s)
Histology showing lymphocytic interface dermatitis with dyskeratotic keratinocytes. (Time: 2636s)

definition: A proliferation of mast cells in the skin that can lead to blister formation, particularly in children.
clinical: Children presenting with diffuse erythema or plaques (Urticaria Pigmentosa) that blister. Positive Darier sign.
pathogenesis: Mast cell accumulation; release of mediators causes subepidermal separation.
macroscopic: Bullae, often on a background of thickened or pigmented skin.
microscopic: Subepidermal blister containing Mast Cells. Mast cells have a 'fried egg' appearance (central nucleus, granular cytoplasm). Eosinophils are frequently present.
prognosis_and_prediction: Cutaneous forms in children often spontaneously regress.
